page.title: 06The Buttress
page.content: The{Buttress}used to be a main road. To go over the tops was a very important way from{Halifax}to{Hebden {Bridge.}This was because of woollen cloth which was colled by packhorse from hand loom weaves in the upland cottages and farms and also because the valleys were originally very swampy and the hillways were easier. The route to{Lancashire}climbed the Buttress after crossing the Old Bridge, crossed the site of the present road and went up to Heptonstall. The route can still be followed above today's present road. The cobbled Buttress as well as the Old Bridge is still very much the same. It has not changed much in three or four hundred years, except that houses at the bottom have been pulled down and widened at that point.
